prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. Find the product of $1011_2 \cdot 101_2$.  Express your answer in base 2.
solution:
We carry out the multiplication as we carry out multiplication in base $10$. Fortunately, we do not have to worry about carrying over, since we are only multiplying by digits of $0$ or $1$. Thus:  $$ \begin{array}{@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1_2 \\
& & & \times & 1 & 0 & 1_2 \\
\cline{4-7} & & & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1_2 \\
& & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0_2 \\
+ & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0_2 \\ \cline{1-7}
& 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\
\end{array}$$When summing, we need to carry-over for the second digit from the left. Thus, the sum is equal to $\boxed{110111}_2$.
gpt_response:
To find the product of $1011_2 \cdot 101_2$, we can perform multiplication in the same way as in base 10, but with the rules for binary arithmetic.

Starting from the rightmost digit of the second number $101_2$, we multiply by each digit of the first number $1011_2$ and shift the result one position to the left for each digit.

$1011_2 \times 1 = 1011_2$
$1011_2 \times 0 = 0000_2$
$1011_2 \times 1 = 1011_2$

Now, we sum up these results:

$1011_2
\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\
\times& & & 1 & 0 & 1 \\
\cline{1-6}
& & & & 1 & 1 & \\
& & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \\
+ & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 & & \\
\cline{1-6}
& 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 &
\end{array}$

Therefore, $1011_2 \cdot 101_2 = 11001_2$.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 110111?: To find the product of $1011_2 \cdot 101_2$, we can perform multiplication in the same way as in base 10, but with the rules for binary arithmetic.

Starting from the rightmost digit of the second number $101_2$, we multiply by each digit of the first number $1011_2$ and shift the result one position to the left for each digit.

$1011_2 \times 1 = 1011_2$
$1011_2 \times 0 = 0000_2$
$1011_2 \times 1 = 1011_2$

Now, we sum up these results:

$1011_2
\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\
\times& & & 1 & 0 & 1 \\
\cline{1-6}
& & & & 1 & 1 & \\
& & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \\
+ & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 & & \\
\cline{1-6}
& 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 &
\end{array}$

Therefore, $1011_2 \cdot 101_2 = 11001_2$.
